posts.name: Steven Pearson
posts.cooked: We are looking to improve our prototyping for next year.  Does anyone have any good suggestions on how to prototype quickly?

posts.name: Everett33
posts.cooked:
1/4" Plywood

2x4s

PVC Pipe

1.125" hole saw

A way to hook a cordless drill to a 1/2" Hex shaft

Electrical tape for quick hex shaft spacers

An assortment of squish and other wheels

Brushed motors like cims, mini cims, bag motors so you dont need to program anything

There are a lot of existing threads on tools, techniques, and ecosystems team have developed with 3D printed parts to make prototype assembly and testign faster.

OTB Intake Prototyping System CAD

Protopipe - Spectrum 3847 Technical Discussion

How do you effectively prototype? CAD

How to make rough prototypes quickly? General Forum

Suggestions for Prototyping Equipment General Forum

link_counts.title: How to make rough prototypes quickly?

posts.name: Ian
posts.cooked:
I like to logically split prototyping into two groups: archetype prototyping and variable prototyping. Archetype prototyping for this year looked something like “Should we do horizontal or vertical flywheel sets?”, variable prototyping this year was “how much compression should the shooter have on the note?”.

The biggest thing to remember when prototyping is you’re not trying to optimize it, you want it do quick and dirty and good enough to answer your question. Our early prototypes were jigsawed 3/4" plywood with random lengths of 0.5" hex shaft we had around and electrical tape spacers driven by drills with a 1/2" socket. Once we decided on our archetype, we then got a little more fancy as we honed in on our solution, CNCd plywood and whatnot.

The attached picture is one of our later prototypes image 638×552 65.8 KB

image 638×552 65.8 KB

image 638×552 65.8 KB

posts.name: Eric Binu
posts.cooked: How do y’all attach a drill to a hex shaft or churro?

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
Also, while regular hex shaft doesn’t usually fit into a 1/2" cordless drill chuck, rounded hex (e.g., REV Rounded Hex) sometimes does.

This is very useful for answering certain questions, such as, “which wheel is grippiest?”.  Instead of putting together a whole rig, you can stick a single wheel on the shaft and retain it with a shaft collar.  Unlike a 1/2" socket, it won’t drop out of the drill, and you don’t need to have something else pushing on the far side to retain the shaft.

If you have something with a longer overhang, it’s better to build a frame, install bearings, and use the socket.
